NAME: A1-Alpha2 Repression
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; conditional mutant is heat sensitive, loses viability at elevated temperature and displays elevated colony sectoring, indicative of chromosome instability; reduction of function mutant has increased telomere length, and decreased competitive fitness in minimal medium
DESCRIPTION: Component of the U5 snRNP complex; required for splicing of U3 precursors; originally described as a splicing factor specifically required for splicing pre-mRNA of the MATa1 cistron

NAME: Aspartate AminoTransferase
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutant has a reduced respiratory growth rate and decreased competitive fitness on non-fermentable carbon sources; null has reduced groth on minimal medium and a reduced ability to use proline as a nitrogen source; null mutant has a reduction in caloric restriction-mediated lifespan extension, while overexpression enhances both chronological and replicative lifespan; overexpression increases silencing at the rDNA locus; null mutant has enhanced biofilm formation; heterozygous null mutant is haploinsufficient
DESCRIPTION: Mitochondrial aspartate aminotransferase; catalyzes the conversion of oxaloacetate to aspartate in aspartate and asparagine biosynthesis

NAME: Aspartate AminoTransferase
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene in S288C, but essential in the Sigma1278b background; S288C null mutant displays a decreased growth rate and decreased competitive fitness in rich medium, temperature sensitivity, and a decreased respiratory growth rate; null mutant is sensitive to DNA synthesis inhibitors, DNA damaging agents and topoisomerase inhibitors; null mutant has decreased resistance to hyperosmotic stress, metals, and zymolyase; null mutant displays decreased chronological lifespan; homozygous null mutant has decreased sporulation efficiency
DESCRIPTION: Cytosolic aspartate aminotransferase involved in nitrogen metabolism; localizes to peroxisomes in oleate-grown cells

PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; temperature-sensitive mutation causes decreasing protein synthesis upon temperature shift; repression leads to abnormal protein secretion
DESCRIPTION: Methyltransferase; catalyzes the transfer of a methyl group from S-adenosylmethionine to the GpppN terminus of capped mRNA; nuclear protein that relocalizes to the cytosol in response to hypoxia

NAME: ARS-Binding Factor 1
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; overexpression variously reported to cause sensitivity to nocodazol, decreased growth rate, or lethality; conditional mutants show delayed progression through G2 phase
DESCRIPTION: DNA binding protein with possible chromatin-reorganizing activity; involved in transcriptional activation, gene silencing, and DNA replication and repair

NAME: ARS-Binding Factor
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutant is incapable of respiratory growth, sensitive to hyperosmotic stress, and shows defects in mitochondrial genome maintenance; overexpression causes abnormal budding and cell cycle progression through G2 phase
DESCRIPTION: Mitochondrial DNA-binding protein; involved in mitochondrial DNA replication and recombination, member of HMG1 DNA-binding protein family; activity may be regulated by protein kinase A phosphorylation; ABF2 has a paralog, IXR1, that arose from the whole genome duplication; human homolog TFAM can complement yeast abf2 mutant, rescuing the loss-of-mitochondrial DNA phenotype in a yeast abf2 strain

NAME: Acetyl-CoA Carboxylase
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; conditional mutants accumulate poly(A) RNA in the nucleus; overexpression leads to increased lipid accumulation; reduction of function results in chromosome instability, decreased competitive fitness, heat sensitivity
DESCRIPTION: Acetyl-CoA carboxylase, biotin containing enzyme; catalyzes carboxylation of cytosolic acetyl-CoA to form malonyl-CoA and regulates histone acetylation by regulating the availablity of acetyl-CoA; required for de novo biosynthesis of long-chain fatty acids; ACC1 has a paralog, HFA1, that arose from the whole genome duplication

NAME: ACOnitase
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows glutamate auxotrophy, sensitivity to hyperosmotic stress, increased accumulation of iron in the mitochondria, loss of mitochondrial genome and deficiency in respiratory growth
DESCRIPTION: Aconitase; required for the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle and also independently required for mitochondrial genome maintenance; component of the mitochondrial nucleoid; mutation leads to glutamate auxotrophy; human homolog ACO2 can complement yeast null mutant

NAME: Acyl Carrier Protein
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene in S288C, but non-essential in another background; S288C-derived null mutant is viable but slow growing when cultured anaerobically; non-essential null mutant is petite and displays decreased accumulation of lipoic acid; reduction of function mutant displays decreased competitive fitness in minimal medium, chromosomal instability, and decreased resistance to hydroxyurea and MMS; overexpression results in increased resistance to dihydromotuporamine C, a tumor cell invasion inhibitor; heterozygous null mutant is haploinsufficient
DESCRIPTION: Mitochondrial matrix acyl carrier protein; involved in biosynthesis of octanoate, which is a precursor to lipoic acid; activated by phosphopantetheinylation catalyzed by Ppt2p

NAME: Acetyl CoA Synthetase
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutant is capable of respiratory growth on non-fermentable carbon sources, but incapable of fermentative growth on glucose as a carbon source
DESCRIPTION: Acetyl-coA synthetase isoform; along with Acs1p, acetyl-coA synthetase isoform is the nuclear source of acetyl-coA for histone acetylation; mutants affect global transcription; required for growth on glucose; expressed under anaerobic conditions

NAME: ACTin
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; conditional mutants show pleiotropic defects including abnormal actin cytoskeleton, chromosome instability, altered subcellular morphology, increased sensitivity to heat, multiple chemicals and osmotic stress; overexpression leads to growth arrest
DESCRIPTION: Actin; structural protein involved in cell polarization, endocytosis, and other cytoskeletal functions

NAME: transcriptional ADAptor
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows altered transcription of multiple genes, weakened cell wall and decreased growth rate; in systematic studies null mutant shows inositol auxotrophy, increased sensitivity to multiple chemicals, alkaline pH and heat
DESCRIPTION: Transcription coactivator; component of the ADA and SAGA transcriptional adaptor/HAT (histone acetyltransferase) complexes

NAME: ADEnine requiring
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene in S288C; reduction-of-function mutations result in adenine auxotrophy
DESCRIPTION: Adenylosuccinate lyase; catalyzes two steps in the 'de novo' purine nucleotide biosynthetic pathway; expression is repressed by adenine and activated by Bas1p and Pho2p; mutations in human ortholog ADSL cause adenylosuccinase deficiency; human ADSL can complement yeast ADE13 null mutant

NAME: ADEnine requiring
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays adenine auxotrophy, forms red colonies and is sensitive to purine analogs; in large-scale studies null mutant shows decreased competitive fitness and shortened chronological lifespan
DESCRIPTION: Phosphoribosylaminoimidazole carboxylase; catalyzes a step in the 'de novo' purine nucleotide biosynthetic pathway; red pigment accumulates in mutant cells deprived of adenine

NAME: ATPase ExPression
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; in systematic studies, null mutant is incapable of respiratory growth and grows slowly under standard fermentative growth conditions; also shows sensitivity to lipids, lower resistance to ethanol, abnormal mitochondrial morphology and decreased mitophagy; homozygous null mutation in diploids causes sensitivity to oxidative stress, but increases innate thermotolerance and resistance to benomyl, actinomycin D, Calcofluor White, idarubicin and tirapazamine
DESCRIPTION: Protein required for expression of the mitochondrial OLI1 gene; mitochondrial OLI1 gene encodes subunit 9 of F1-F0 ATP synthase

NAME: ATPase ExPression
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutant is unable to grow under respiratory growth conditions; in systematic studies, null mutant shows slow growth under fermentative growth condtions, produces small-size cells, has abnormal mitochondrial morphology and lower resistance to ethanol; in diploids under competitive growth conditions, homozygous null mutation results in sensitivity to oxidative stress and increased resistance to cell wall-affecting chemicals, such as caffeine and Calcofluor White, and to DNA-damaging factors, such as MMS, idarubicin, melphalan
DESCRIPTION: Mitochondrial protein; likely involved in translation of the mitochondrial OLI1 mRNA; exhibits genetic interaction with the OLI1 mRNA 5'-untranslated leader

NAME: ATPase ExPression
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutation increases frequency of mitochondrial genome loss (rho- mutations) and leads to respiratory growth defect; in systematic studies, null mutant grows slowly, produces small cells and shows strong vacuolar fragmentation; in diploids under competitive growth conditions, homozygous null mutation results in sensitivity to oxidative stress and increased resistance to cell wall-affecting chemicals, such as caffeine and Calcofluor White, and to DNA-damaging factors, such as MMS, idarubicin, melphalan
DESCRIPTION: Peripheral mitochondrial inner membrane protein; may facilitate use of unformylated tRNA-Met in mitochondrial translation initiation; stabilizes the bicistronic AAP1-ATP6 mRNA

NAME: ATPase Family Gene
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; repression leads to defects in nuclear export and accumulation of large ribosomal subunits in the nucleus; repression also results in opi- phenotype (overproduction and excretion of inositol in the absence of inositol and choline)
DESCRIPTION: ATPase of the CDC48/PAS1/SEC18 (AAA) family, forms a hexameric complex; is essential for pre-60S maturation and release of several preribosome maturation factors; releases Rlp24p from purified pre-60S particles in vitro; target of the ribosomal biosynthesis inhibitor diazaborine; may be involved in degradation of aberrant mRNAs

NAME: ATPase Family Gene
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutant is unable to use nonfermentable carbon sources and has a lengthened replicative lifespan, although lifespan extension by caloric restriction is less than in wild type; null mutant displays increased resistance to oxidative and heat stress; null mutant accumulates decreased levels of cardiolipin in mitochondrial membranes; in large-scale studies, null mutant shows reduced competitive fitness and altered sensitivity to a variety of drugs
DESCRIPTION: Mitochondrial inner membrane m-AAA protease component; mediates degradation of misfolded or unassembled proteins; also required for correct assembly of mitochondrial enzyme complexes; involved in cytoplasmic mRNA translation and aging; expression of human homolog AFG3L2 can complement yeast yta12 afg3 double mutant

NAME: Activator of Ferrous Transport
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays a decreased growth rate, reduced competitive fitness and respiratory growth defects; null mutant is sensitive to metals, alkaline pH, and a variety of chemicals; null mutant displays chromosome instability, has decreased cell size and delayed progression through the G1 phase of the cell cycle; ovexpression and constitutively active alleles also display decreased growth rates
DESCRIPTION: Transcription factor involved in iron utilization and homeostasis; binds consensus site PyPuCACCCPu and activates transcription in response to changes in iron availability; in iron-replete conditions localization is regulated by Grx3p, Grx4p, and Fra2p, and promoter binding is negatively regulated via Grx3p-Grx4p binding; AFT1 has a paralog, AFT2, that arose from the whole genome duplication; relative distribution to the nucleus increases upon DNA replication stress

NAME: Altered Inheritance rate of Mitochondria
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutant is heat sensitive, has a vegetative growth defect, a respiratory growth defect and displays reduced competitive fitness in various media; null mutant has a decreased ability to utilize the carbon source galactose and the nitrogen sources, glutamine and proline; null mutant displays a decreased frequency of spontaneous mitochondrial genome loss but an elevated nuclear mutation frequency; null mutant has a small cell size, decreased chronological lifespan, decreased desiccation resistance, and displays a reduction in the number of lipid particles per cell; heterozygous null mutant is haploinsufficient
DESCRIPTION: Protein with similarity to tRNA synthetases; non-tagged protein is detected in purified mitochondria; null mutant is viable and displays elevated frequency of mitochondrial genome loss

NAME: Altered Inheritance rate of Mitochondria
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays decreased competitive fitness in media containing either fermentable or non-fermentable carbon sources, and a decreased rate of respiratory growth; null mutant displays an increased frequency of spontaneous mitochondrial genome loss; null mutant has decreased chronological lifespan, decreased desiccation resistance and is defective in biofilm formation; null mutant is inhibited by palmitoleic acid but stimulated by oleic acid
DESCRIPTION: Protein of unknown function; null mutant is viable but shows increased loss of mitochondrial genome and synthetic interaction with prohibitin (phb1); contains an intron; SWAT-GFP and mCherry fusion proteins localize to the mitochondria; YER093C-A has a paralog, YBL059W, that arose from the whole genome duplication

NAME: Altered Inheritance rate of Mitochondria
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays decreased competitive fitness in various media, a decreased respiratory growth rate, and decreased rate of utilization of various carbon and nitrogen sources; null mutant has a reduced cell size, increased heat sensitivity, and decreased chronological lifespan; null mutant displays a reduced frequency of spontaneous mitochondrial genome loss and elevated levels of Rnr3p, indicative of genome instability; null mutant contains severely reduced lipoate levels and is unable to lipoylate several mitochondrial enzymes; null mutant has decreased resistance to oxidative stress and desiccation but increased resistance to zinc deficiency
DESCRIPTION: Putative lipoate-protein ligase; required along with Lip2 and Lip5 for lipoylation of Lat1p and Kgd2p; similar to E. coli LplA; null mutant displays reduced frequency of mitochondrial genome loss

NAME: Altered Inheritance rate of Mitochondria
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene in S288C, but essential in the SK1 background; S288C null mutant has a small cell size in a saturated culture, a decreased growth rate on fermentable and nonfermentable carbon sources, decreased competitive fitness on various media, and a reduction in the ability to utilize galactose as carbon source and arginine or glutamate as nitrogen sources; null mutant displays an increased frequency of spontaneous mitochondrial genome loss and has defects in both mitophagy and autophagy; null has decreased innate thermotolerance, decreased chronological lifespan, decreased resistance to desiccation, and decreased resistance to both gliotoxin and killer toxin
DESCRIPTION: Protein of unknown function; null mutant is viable and displays elevated frequency of mitochondrial genome loss; null mutation confers sensitivity to tunicamycin and DTT

NAME: Altered Inheritance rate of Mitochondria
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays decreased rates of fermentative and respiratory growth, and decreased competitive fitness in various media; null mutant accumulates mother cells that retain a connection to two or more buds, displays a thin secondary septum, a reduction in the accumulation of Rho1p at the bud neck after actomyosin ring (AMR) contraction, and an abnormal reaccumulation of Cdc42p at bud neck after AMR contraction, all indicative of abnormal coordination of cytokinesis and polarity establishment; null mutant displays an increased frequency of spontaneous mitochondrial genome loss; null mutant has increased chitin deposition, decreased endocytosis and decreased peroxisomal protein transport; overexpression results in decreased filamentation and invasive growth in the presence of short-chain alcohols and increased invasive growth in nitrogen-sufficient medium
DESCRIPTION: Regulator of Cdc42p and Rho1p; regulates AMR closure through Hof1p; inhibits Cdc42-dependent Cla4 activation at the division site, to prevent budding in the old bud neck; recruits Nis1p and Nba1p to the division site with Nap1 and the Rax1p-Rax2p dependent inheritance of Nis1p and Nba1p to bud scars to prevent division site repolarization; keeps Rho1p at the division site after AMR contraction to control secondary septum formation; relocalizes from bud neck to cytoplasm upon replication stress

NAME: ALAnyl-tRNA synthetase
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; conditional mutants are impaired in cell cycle progression at elevated temperatures; reduced function mutants show decreased competitive fitness and have shortened telomeres; heterozygous diploid nulls are sensitive to zinc chloride and to oxidative stress; overexpression slows vegetative growth in S288C, increases invasive growth in Sigma1278b
DESCRIPTION: Cytoplasmic and mitochondrial alanyl-tRNA synthetase; required for protein synthesis; point mutation (cdc64-1 allele) causes cell cycle arrest at G1; lethality of null mutation is functionally complemented by human homolog AARS; mutations in human homolog AARS are associated with autoimmune disease polymyositis/dermatomyositis

NAME: Asparagine-Linked Glycosylation
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; conditional mutants are senstive to heat and impaired in invertase glycosylation; reduced function mutants show increased competitive fitness, increased sensitivity to DNA-damaging agent methyl methanesulfonate (MMS); heterozygous diploid nulls are sensitive to starvation
DESCRIPTION: Mannosyltransferase; involved in asparagine-linked glycosylation in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER); essential for viability; human homolog ALG1 complements yeast null mutant

NAME: Asparagine-Linked Glycosylation
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; reduced function mutants show decreased competitive fitness, increased sensitivity to rapamycin and to DNA-damaging agents methyl methanesulfonate (MMS) and hydroxyurea (HU); heterozygous diploid nulls have small cells
DESCRIPTION: Catalytic component of UDP-GlcNAc transferase; required for the second step of dolichyl-linked oligosaccharide synthesis; anchored to the ER membrane via interaction with Alg14p; similar to bacterial and human glycosyltransferases; protein abundance increases in response to DNA replication stress; both human homologs ALG13 and ALG14 are required to complement yeast alg13 mutant

NAME: Asparagine Linked Glycosylation
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; conditional mutants are sensitive to heat; reduced function mutants show increased competitive fitness, increased sensitivity to DNA-damaging agent methyl methanesulfonate (MMS) and to heat; repression increases chromosome rearrangements and chromosome loss
DESCRIPTION: Component of UDP-GlcNAc transferase; required for second step of dolichyl-linked oligosaccharide synthesis; anchors catalytic subunit Alg13p to ER membrane; similar to bacterial and human glycosyltransferases; both human homologs ALG13 and ALG14 are required to complement yeast alg14 mutant

NAME: Asparagine-Linked Glycosylation
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; mutations cause sensitivity to gentamycin, hygromycin B, kanamycin and neomycin B; repression leads to increased sensitivity to MMS and myriocin; overexpression results in slow growth
DESCRIPTION: Mannosyltransferase in the N-linked glycosylation pathway; catalyzes two consecutive steps in the N-linked glycosylation pathway; alg2 mutants exhibit temperature-sensitive growth and abnormal accumulation of the lipid-linked oligosaccharide Man2GlcNAc2-PP-Dol; human ALG2 complements the temperature sensitivity and dolichol-linked oligosaccharide biosynthesis defect of the alg2-1 mutant, but mutant form from a patient with CDG-Ii fails to complement

NAME: Asparagine-Linked Glycosylation
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; activation blocks sporulation, increases resistance to GlcNAc phosphotransferase (GPT) inhibitor tunicamycin; reduced function mutants show decreased competitive fitness, decreased resistance to tunicamycin; repression causes loss of the mitochondrial genome, and decreased accumulation of dolichol-linked oligosaccharides; heterozygous diploid nulls are sensitive to tunicamycin
DESCRIPTION: UDP-N-acetyl-glucosamine-1-P transferase; transfers Glc-Nac-P from UDP-GlcNac to Dol-P in the ER in the first step of the dolichol pathway of protein asparagine-linked glycosylation; inhibited by tunicamycin; human homolog DPAGT1 can complement yeast ALG7 mutant

NAME: ALuminum Resistance
PHENOTYPE: Null mutants grow very slowly; reduced function mutants show decreased competitive fitness, increased sensitivity to microtubule-destabilizing agent benomyl; overexpression slows growth, increases sensitivity to rapamycin
DESCRIPTION: Plasma membrane Mg(2+) transporter; expression and turnover are regulated by Mg(2+) concentration; overexpression confers increased tolerance to Al(3+) and Ga(3+) ions; magnesium transport defect of the null mutant is functionally complemented by either of the human genes MAGT1 and TUSC3 that are not orthologous to ALR1

NAME: Associated with Microtubules and Essential
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; conditional mutant is heat sensitive, arresting in anaphase at the restrictive temperature, and displays reduced vegetative growth at permissive temperatures; conditional, repressible and heterozygous null mutants display chromosomal instability, including elevated chromosome loss and chromosomal rearrangements; overexpression results in the accumulation of large-budded cells with 2C DNA content, indicative of a G2 or M phase delay or arrest
DESCRIPTION: Essential kinetochore protein associated with microtubules and SPBs; component of the kinetochore sub-complex COMA (Ctf19p, Okp1p, Mcm21p, Ame1p); involved in spindle checkpoint maintenance; orthologous to human centromere constitutive-associated network (CCAN) subunit CENP-U and fission yeast Mis17; relative distribution to the nucleus increases upon DNA replication stress

NAME: Activation Of Smt3p
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; repression leads to opi- phenotype (overproduction and excretion of inositol in the absence of inositol and choline)
DESCRIPTION: Subunit of heterodimeric nuclear SUMO activating enzyme E1 with Uba2p; activates Smt3p (SUMO) before its conjugation to proteins (sumoylation), which may play a role in protein targeting; essential for viability; relocalizes to the cytosol in response to hypoxia

NAME: Anaphase Promoting Complex subunit
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; reduction of function increases competitive fitness
DESCRIPTION: Largest subunit of the Anaphase-Promoting Complex/Cyclosome; APC/C is a ubiquitin-protein ligase required for degradation of anaphase inhibitors, including mitotic cyclins, during the metaphase/anaphase transition; component of the platform domain of the APC/C, based on structural analysis; localizes to nuclear foci that become diffuse upon DNA replication stress

NAME: Anaphase Promoting Complex
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutants show cell cycle arrest at G2/M phase transition, abnormal spindle morphology, chromosome instability and sensitivity to hydroxyurea
DESCRIPTION: Catalytic core subunit, Anaphase-Promoting Complex/Cyclosome (APC/C); which is a ubiquitin-protein ligase required for degradation of anaphase inhibitors, including mitotic cyclins, during the metaphase/anaphase transition; contains a RING-H2 domain that is required for activity

NAME: Anaphase Promoting Complex
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; reduction of function decreases competitive fitness; haploproficient but heterozygous diploid is sensitive to starvation
DESCRIPTION: Subunit of the Anaphase-Promoting Complex/Cyclosome (APC/C); which is a ubiquitin-protein ligase required for degradation of anaphase inhibitors, including mitotic cyclins, during the metaphase/anaphase transition; component of the catalytic core of the APC/C; has similarity to cullin Cdc53p

NAME: Anaphase Promoting Complex
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutant shows chromosome instability; reduction of function leads to reduced telomere length and increased competitive fitness
DESCRIPTION: Subunit of the Anaphase-Promoting Complex/Cyclosome (APC/C); APC/C is a ubiquitin-protein ligase required for degradation of anaphase inhibitors, including mitotic cyclins, during the metaphase/anaphase transition; component of the platform domain of the APC/C, based on structural analysis; relative distribution to the nucleus increases upon DNA replication stress

NAME: Anaphase Promoting Complex
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; reduction-of-function mutations cause cell cycle arrest at G2/M phase transition, increased competitive fitness and shortened chronological and replicative lifespan; some mutations elevate resistance to benomyl and cycloheximide
DESCRIPTION: Subunit of the Anaphase-Promoting Complex/Cyclosome (APC/C); APC/C is a ubiquitin-protein ligase required for degradation of anaphase inhibitors, including mitotic cyclins, during the metaphase/anaphase transition; component of the platform domain of the APC/C, based on structural analysis; relative distribution to nuclear foci decreases upon DNA replication stress

NAME: APurinic/apyrimidinic eNdonuclease
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows increased mutation frequency and sensitivity to topoisomerase inhibitor beta-lapachone; in large-scale studies null mutants show no respiratory growth and reduced mitophagy
DESCRIPTION: Class II abasic (AP) endonuclease involved in repair of DNA damage; resolves blocked 3' ends that result from removal of misincorporated nucleotides; homolog of human HAP1 and E. coli exoIII

NAME: ATP-binding cassette protein involved in Ribosome Biogenesis
PHENOTYPE: Null mutants are inviable under standard aerobic conditions, viable but slow-growing under anaerobic conditions; reduced function mutants show decreased competitive fitness
DESCRIPTION: ATPase of the ATP-binding cassette (ABC) family; involved in 40S and 60S ribosome biogenesis, has similarity to Gcn20p; shuttles from nucleus to cytoplasm, physically interacts with Tif6p, Lsg1p; human homolog ABCF2 can complement yeast ARB1 mutant

NAME: ARp2/3 Complex subunit
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutant forms abnormal actin cytoskeleton structures, grows very slowly and produces spores with low viability
DESCRIPTION: Subunit of the ARP2/3 complex; ARP2/3 is required for the motility and integrity of cortical actin patches; has mRNA binding activity

NAME: ARp2/3 Complex subunit
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutant forms aberrant actin structures, grows very slowly, and produces spores with reduced viability
DESCRIPTION: Subunit of the ARP2/3 complex; ARP2/3 is required for the motility and integrity of cortical actin patches; mutation is functionally complemented by human ARPC4

NAME: ARp2/3 Complex subunit
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutant forms aberrant actin structures, grows very slowly, and produces spores with reduced viability; conditional (ts) mutant shows decreased endocytosis and increased sensitivity to hyperosmotic stress; repression causes abnormal mitochondrial morphology and confers resistance to myriocin
DESCRIPTION: Subunit of the ARP2/3 complex; ARP2/3 is required for the motility and integrity of cortical actin patches; required for cortical localization of calmodulin

NAME: ARp2/3 Complex subunit
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutant forms aberrant actin structures, grows very slowly, and produces spores with reduced viability; repression causes abnormal mitochondrial morphology, elevated excretion of inositol and confers resistance to myriocin
DESCRIPTION: Subunit of the ARP2/3 complex; ARP2/3 is required for the motility and integrity of cortical actin patches

NAME: ARrest Defective
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays decreased pheromone sensitivity, reduced mating efficiency and sporulation, decreased respiratory growth; increased heat sensitivity and decreased innate thermotolerance; null mutation also decreases survival rate in stationary phase
DESCRIPTION: Subunit of protein N-terminal acetyltransferase NatA; NatA comprises Nat1p, Ard1p, Nat5p; acetylates many proteins to influence telomeric silencing, cell cycle, heat-shock resistance, mating, sporulation, early stages of mitophagy; protein abundance increases under DNA replication stress; mutations in human homolog X-linked NAA10 lead to Ogden syndrome (S37P) and intellectual disability (R116W); expression of human NAA10 and NAA15 can complement ard1 nat1 double mutant

NAME: Adrenodoxin Reductase Homolog
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene under standard aerobic conditions; null mutant grows slowly under anaerobic condition; repression casues accumulation of ubiquinone-6; overexpression in Sigma1278b leads to increased invasive growth
DESCRIPTION: Oxidoreductase of the mitochondrial inner membrane; involved in cytoplasmic and mitochondrial iron homeostasis and required for activity of Fe-S cluster-containing enzymes; one of the few mitochondrial proteins essential for viability

NAME: ADP-Ribosylation factor-Like
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutant mislocalizes Golgi protein Arl1p to cytoplasm; null mutant has fragmented vacuoles and shows increased sensitivity to protein glycosylation inhibitor, tunicamycin, and cell wall-affecting dye, Congo Red
DESCRIPTION: ARF-like small GTPase of the RAS superfamily; required for recruitment of Arl1p, a GTPase that regulates membrane traffic, to the Golgi apparatus; NatC-catalyzed N-terminal acetylation regulates Golgi membrane association mediated by interaction with membrane receptor, Sys1p; similar to ADP-ribosylation factor and orthologous to mammalian ARFRP1

NAME: Actin-Related Protein
PHENOTYPE: Essential/non-essential gene; null mutant has been reported to be either viable and slow growing or inviable in S288C; conditional mutant arrests non-uniformly and loses viability; conditional mutant displays abnormal actin cytoskeleton morphology, abnormal bud morphology, a random budding pattern in both haploids and diploids, abnormal chitin deposition, defective endocytosis and sensitivity to hyperosmotic stress; conditional mutant displays decreased mitochondrial movement velocity, loss of directed movement, and abnormal mitochondrial morphology; homozygous conditional diploid has a defect in spore wall formation and a severe sporulation defect; hypomorphic DAmP allele has reduced telomere length
DESCRIPTION: Essential component of the Arp2/3 complex; Arp2/3 is a highly conserved actin nucleation center required for the motility and integrity of actin patches; involved in endocytosis and membrane growth and polarity; required for efficient Golgi-to-ER trafficking in COPI mutants

NAME: Actin-Related Protein
PHENOTYPE: Essential/non-essential gene; null mutant has been reported to be either viable, poorly germinating and slow growing or inviable in S288C; conditional mutant arrests randomly and loses viability at elevated temperature; conditional mutant exhibits decreased actin-cortical patch motility, accumulates aggregates and immobile cables, and replaces cortical actin patches by bundle-like structures; conditional mutant is benomyl sensitive; reduction of function allele has decreased telomere length; heterozygous diploid null is haploinsufficient
DESCRIPTION: Essential component of the Arp2/3 complex; Arp2/3 is a highly conserved actin nucleation center required for the motility and integrity of actin patches; involved in endocytosis and membrane growth and polarity

NAME: Actin-Related Protein
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; conditional mutant has a G1/S phase delay, a metaphase arrest with elevated spindle elongation, breakage associated with lagging chromosomes in mother cells, and abnormal nuclear morphology; conditional mutant has non-uniform stationary phase arrest after prolonged cultivation, with abnormal nuclear morphology and decreased viability; conditional and reduction of function alleles are sensitive to hydroyurea, benomyl and rapamycin; repressible mutant displays increased spontaneous DNA damage and increased excretion of inositol
DESCRIPTION: Nuclear actin-related protein involved in chromatin remodeling; component of chromatin-remodeling enzyme complexes

NAME: Actin-Related Protein
PHENOTYPE: Essential/non-essential gene in S288C; null mutant has been reported to be either viable, and slow growing or inviable in S288C; null mutant is viable and extremely slow growing in W303; S288C-derived viable null is unable to grow on media containing glycerol or sucrose as the sole carbon source and exhibits slow growth on galactose; repressible mutant displays abnormal mitochondrial morphology and increased chromosomal rearrangements and chromosome loss; heterozygous diploid null is haploinsufficient
DESCRIPTION: Component of both the SWI/SNF and RSC chromatin remodeling complexes; actin-related protein involved in transcriptional regulation

NAME: Actin-Related Protein
PHENOTYPE: Essential/non-essential gene in S288C; null mutant has been reported to be either viable, and slow growing or inviable in S288C; null mutant is viable and extremely slow growing in W303; S288C-derived viable null is unable to grow on media containing glycerol, sucrose, or galactose as the sole carbon source; conditional mutant displays elevated chromosomal instability, including increased gross chromosomal rearrangements; heterozygous null mutant is heat sensitive
DESCRIPTION: Component of both the SWI/SNF and RSC chromatin remodeling complexes; actin-related protein involved in transcriptional regulation

NAME: AStra Associated protein
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutation causes cell cycle arrest at G1 phase upon shift to non-permissive temperature and decreased levels of telomere length regulator Tel1p and TORC1 component Tor1p; reduction-of-function mutations confer rapamycin sensitivity and reduced telomere length
DESCRIPTION: Subunit of the ASTRA complex, involved in chromatin remodeling; telomere length regulator involved in the stability or biogenesis of PIKKs such as TORC1

NAME: Associated with Spindles and Kinetochores
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutations cause delayed metaphase-anaphase transition and abnormal spindle morphology; reduction of function leads to decreased competitive fitness
DESCRIPTION: Essential subunit of the Dam1 complex (aka DASH complex); couples kinetochores to the force produced by MT depolymerization thereby aiding in chromosome segregation; phosphorylated during the cell cycle by cyclin-dependent kinases; sumoylated in an Mms21p-dependent manner; protein abundance increases in response to DNA replication stress

NAME: AuTophaGy related
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutant is defective in autophagy, mitophagy and pexophagy; shows slow growth rate, decreased lifespan and sensitivity to nitrogen starvation
DESCRIPTION: Scaffold protein responsible for phagophore assembly site organization; regulatory subunit of an autophagy-specific complex that includes Atg1p and Atg13p; stimulates Atg1p kinase activity; human ortholog RB1CC1/FIP200 interacts with p53, which inhibits autophagy in human cells

NAME: ABC Transporter, Mitochondrial
PHENOTYPE: Null mutants are inviable under standard aerobic conditions, viable but slow-growing under anaerobic conditions; null mutant cells accumulate glutathione disulfide, and mitochondria contain increased levels of free iron; heterozygous diploid nulls are haploinsufficient, sensitive to starvation and to the Sir2 histone deacetylase inhibitor tenovin-6; reduced function mutants show increased competitive fitness and chromosome instability
DESCRIPTION: Mitochondrial inner membrane ATP-binding cassette (ABC) transporter; exports mitochondrially synthesized precursors of iron-sulfur (Fe/S) clusters to the cytosol; human homolog ABCB7 can complement yeast null mutant

NAME: ATP synthase
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutant has a decreased growth rate on rich medium, a severe respiratory growth defect, a decreased ability to utilize various nitrogen sources, decreased competitive fitness on a variety of media and decreased starvation resistance; null mutant has a reduced cell size; null mutant displays a reduced survival rate in stationary phase and decreased glycogen accumulation; null mutant has a reduced chronological lifespan (CLS), while gain-of-function mutants have increased CLS; null mutant has an elevated dietary restriction-induced replicative lifespan extension; null mutant has decreased resistance to acid and alkaline pH, desiccation and innate thermotolerance
DESCRIPTION: Alpha subunit of the F1 sector of mitochondrial F1F0 ATP synthase; which is a large, evolutionarily conserved enzyme complex required for ATP synthesis; F1 translationally regulates ATP6 and ATP8 expression to achieve a balanced output of ATP synthase genes encoded in nucleus and mitochondria; phosphorylated; N-terminally propionylated in vivo

NAME: ATP synthase
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutant is incapable of respiratory growth on non-fermentable carbon sources; null mutant also shows decreased rate of vegetative growth ("petite" phenotype), no sporulation, and reduced autophagy
DESCRIPTION: Assembly factor for the F0 sector of mitochondrial F1F0 ATP synthase; mitochondrial inner membrane protein; interacts genetically with ATP6

NAME: ATP synthase
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutant is incapable of respiratory growth on non-fermentable carbon source and shows no sporulation, increased sensitivity to starvation and oxidative stress, increased resistance to benomyl and caffeine, and decreased resistance to ethanol, MMS, neomycin, streptomycin
DESCRIPTION: Molecular chaperone; required for the assembly of alpha and beta subunits into the F1 sector of mitochondrial F1F0 ATP synthase; N-terminally propionylated in vivo

NAME: ATP synthase
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutant has a severe respiratory growth defect, decreased rate of vegetative growth, decreased utilization of various carbon and nitrogen sources; null mutant has a reduced cell size, displays decreased resistance to heat, manganese, freeze-thaw and oxidative stress; null mutant is petite-negative, displays decreased mitophagy, decreased chronological lifespan, decreased glycogen accumulation, abnormal mitochondrial morphology, and elevated rates of mini-chromosome loss
DESCRIPTION: Assembly factor for F1 sector of mitochondrial F1F0 ATP synthase; conserved protein; required for assembly of alpha and beta subunits into F1 sector of mitochondrial F1F0 ATP synthase; human homolog ATPAF2 can complement yeast atp12 mutant; mutation of human homolog reduces active ATP synthase levels and is associated with the disorder ATPAF2 deficiency

NAME: ATP synthase
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutant is incapable of respiratory growth on non-fermentable carbon source and shows no sporulation, abnormal mitochondrial morphology and increased frequency of mitochondrial genome loss (rho- mutations); in systematic studies null mutant shows reduced competitive fitness; in Sigma1278b null mutant shows greatly decreased filamentous growth
DESCRIPTION: Subunit h of the F0 sector of mitochondrial F1F0 ATP synthase; F1F0 ATP synthase is a large, evolutionarily conserved enzyme complex required for ATP synthesis; protein abundance increases in response to DNA replication stress

NAME: ATP synthase
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutant is unable to grow on non-fermentable carbon sources, indicating respiratory growth defect; in systematic studies null mutants are sensitive to Congo Red, MMS, rapamycin, but resistant to miconazole, and show reduced competitive fitness
DESCRIPTION: Epsilon subunit of the F1 sector of mitochondrial F1F0 ATP synthase; which is a large, evolutionarily conserved enzyme complex required for ATP synthesis; F1 translationally regulates ATP6 and ATP8 expression to achieve a balanced output of ATP synthase genes encoded in nucleus and mitochondria; phosphorylated

NAME: ATP synthase
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutation causes "petite" phenotype - slow growth on glucose and no growth with non-fermentable carbon sources, indicating respiratory deficiency; null mutant also shows increased frequency of mitochondrial genome loss (rho- mutations)
DESCRIPTION: Delta subunit of the central stalk of mitochondrial F1F0 ATP synthase; F1F0 ATP synthase is a large, evolutionarily conserved enzyme complex required for ATP synthesis; F1 translationally regulates ATP6 and ATP8 expression to achieve a balanced output of ATP synthase genes encoded in nucleus and mitochondria; phosphorylated

NAME: ATP synthase
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutation causes "petite" phenotype - slow growth on glucose and no growth with non-fermentable carbon sources, indicating respiratory deficiency; null mutant also shows increased frequency of mitochondrial genome loss (rho- mutations) and increased number of peroxisomes
DESCRIPTION: Subunit f of the F0 sector of mitochondrial F1F0 ATP synthase; F1F0 ATP synthase is a large, evolutionarily conserved enzyme complex required for ATP synthesis

NAME: ATP synthase
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutation causes "petite" phenotype - slow growth on glucose and no growth with non-fermentable carbon sources, indicating respiratory deficiency; null mutant also shows increased frequency of mitochondrial genome loss (rho- mutations)
DESCRIPTION: Subunit of the mitochondrial F1F0 ATP synthase; F1F0 ATP synthase is a large, evolutionarily conserved enzyme complex required for ATP synthesis; termed subunit I or subunit j; does not correspond to known ATP synthase subunits in other organisms

NAME: ATP synthase
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene, but heterozygous diploid shows haploinsufficiency; null mutant is temperature sensitive, petite-negative, has a decreased rate of survival in stationary phase, a glycogen accumulation defect, decreased starvation resistance, a respiratory growth defect and decreased resistance to desiccation and oxidative stress; null mutant has a competitive fitness defect in various media and abnormal mitochondrial and vacuolar morphologies
DESCRIPTION: Beta subunit of the F1 sector of mitochondrial F1F0 ATP synthase; which is a large, evolutionarily conserved enzyme complex required for ATP synthesis; F1 translationally regulates ATP6 and ATP8 expression to achieve a balanced output of ATP synthase genes encoded in nucleus and mitochondria; phosphorylated

NAME: ATPase synthase
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutation causes "petite" phenotype - slow growth on glucose and no growth with non-fermentable carbon sources, indicating respiratory deficiency; null mutant also shows increased frequency of mitochondrial genome loss (rho- mutations); in systematic studies null mutants are sensitive to caspofungin, Congo Red, hydroxyurea
DESCRIPTION: Specific translational activator for the mitochondrial ATP6 mRNA; Atp6p encodes a subunit of F1F0 ATP synthase; localized to the mitochondrial inner membrane

PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutation causes "petite" phenotype - slow growth on glucose and no growth with non-fermentable carbon sources, indicating respiratory deficiency; in systematic studies null mutants are sensitive to starvation and desiccation, and to ethanol and neomycin
DESCRIPTION: Putative metalloprotease of the mitochondrial inner membrane; required for processing of Atp6p; has an additional role in assembly of the F0 sector of the F1F0 ATP synthase complex; substrate of the Mia40p-Erv1p disulfide relay system, and folding is assisted by Mia40p

NAME: ATPase
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutation causes "petite" phenotype - slow growth on glucose and no growth with non-fermentable carbon sources, indicating respiratory deficiency; null mutant also shows increased frequency of mitochondrial genome loss (rho- mutations); in systematic studies null mutants are sensitive to ethanol and palmitoleate, but resistant to miconazole and edelfosine; overexpression in Sigma1278b causes increased invasive growth
DESCRIPTION: Mitochondrial protein required for the stability of Oli1p (Atp9p) mRNA; also required for the Oli1p ring formation; YMR098C is not an essential gene

NAME: ATP synthase
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutant has "petite" phenotype - slow growth on glucose and no growth with non-fermentable carbon sources, indicating respiratory deficiency; null mutant also shows reduced survival rate in stationary phase
DESCRIPTION: Gamma subunit of the F1 sector of mitochondrial F1F0 ATP synthase; F1F0 ATP synthase is a large, evolutionarily conserved enzyme complex required for ATP synthesis

NAME: ATP synthase
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutant has "petite" phenotype - slow growth on glucose and no growth with non-fermentable carbon sources, indicating respiratory deficiency; null mutant also shows abnormalities in mitochondrial genome maintenance and sensitivity to oxidative stress
DESCRIPTION: Subunit b of the stator stalk of mitochondrial F1F0 ATP synthase; ATP synthase is a large, evolutionarily conserved enzyme complex required for ATP synthesis; contributes to the oligomerization of the complex, which in turn determines the shape of inner membrane cristae; phosphorylated

NAME: ATP synthase
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutation causes "petite" phenotype - slow growth on glucose and no growth with non-fermentable carbon sources, indicating respiratory deficiency; in systematic studies null mutants are sensitive to osmotic stress, desiccation, and to several chemicals including streptomycin, tunicamycin, MMS, edelfosine
DESCRIPTION: Subunit 5 of the stator stalk of mitochondrial F1F0 ATP synthase; F1F0 ATP synthase is a large, evolutionarily conserved enzyme complex required for ATP synthesis; homologous to bovine subunit OSCP (oligomycin sensitivity-conferring protein); phosphorylated

NAME: ATP synthase
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutant has "petite" phenotype - slow growth on glucose and no growth with non-fermentable carbon sources, indicating respiratory deficiency; in systematic studies null mutants become resistant to edelfosine, MMS, idarubicin, benomyl, caffeine, but sensitive to UV, cordycepin
DESCRIPTION: Subunit d of the stator stalk of mitochondrial F1F0 ATP synthase; F1F0 ATP synthase is a large, evolutionarily conserved enzyme complex required for ATP synthesis

NAME: AnTioXidant
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutants show decreased competitive fitness, poor anoxic growth, are impaired in respiration, sensitive to cycloheximide, curcumin, antifungal ciclopirox olamine, and cardiovascular drug amiodarone; heterozygous diploid nulls are sensitive to starvation
DESCRIPTION: Cytosolic copper metallochaperone; transports copper to the secretory vesicle copper transporter Ccc2p for eventual insertion into Fet3p, which is a multicopper oxidase required for high-affinity iron uptake; human homolog ATOX1 can complement yeast atx1 mutant; overexpression of human ATOX1 suppresses lysine auxotrophy of the yeast sod1 null mutant, as does overexpression of yeast ATX1

NAME: AUreobasidin A Resistance
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; conditional mutant displays decreased accumulation of ceramide and inositol phosphoceramide; repressible mutant has disassembled intranuclear and cytoplasmic microtubules, a reduction in beta-tubulin levels and diffuse cell surface disposition of chitin; overexpression results in a decreased rate of vegetative growth and hyperosmotic stress resistance; dominant mutant and overexpressor are resistant to aureobasidin A
DESCRIPTION: Phosphatidylinositol:ceramide phosphoinositol transferase; required for sphingolipid synthesis; can mutate to confer aureobasidin A resistance; also known as IPC synthase

NAME: Adheres VOraciously (to TOR2)
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; repressible mutant has a depolarized actin cytoskeleton and small peroxisomes; reduction of function allele has increased resistance to cycloheximide, and decreased resistance to both benomyl and MMS; overexpression results in a reduction in growth rate; heterozygous diploid null is haploinsufficient
DESCRIPTION: Component of a membrane-bound complex containing the Tor2p kinase; contains Tor2p kinase and other proteins; may have a role in regulation of cell growth

NAME: Amino acid Vacuolar Transport
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; in systematic studies null mutants show reduced competitive fitness, weak sensitivity to caffeine, reduced growth on galactose
DESCRIPTION: Putative transporter; member of a family of seven S. cerevisiae genes (AVT1-7) related to vesicular GABA-glycine transporters; AVT5 has a paralog, AVT6, that arose from the whole genome duplication

NAME: Bfr1 Binding Protein
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; conditional mutant is heat sensitive, fails to form a bipolar spindle in mitosis due to the inability to assemble a nuclear inner plaque during SPB duplication; conditional mutant has an M phase delay, a chromosome segregation defect, and an inability to localize Mps2p to the new SPB duplication plaque and Cdc5p to the SPB; repressible mutant displays a budding defect, abnormal chitin deposition, and absence of a mitotic spindle; overexpression at high levels results in inviability, and at lower levels results in a strong growth defect, and an increase in ploidy; overexpression in a diploid results in the formation of asci containing internal asci
DESCRIPTION: Protein required for the spindle pole body (SPB) duplication; localizes at the cytoplasmic side of the central plaque periphery of the SPB; forms a complex with a nuclear envelope protein Mps2p and SPB components Spc29p and Kar1p; required for mitotic functions of Cdc5p

NAME: Box C/D snoRNA accumulation
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; reduction of function mutant has decreased competitive fitness in minimal medium; transposon insertion mutant is unable to undergo invasive growth and has a reduction in filamentous growth; repressible mutant displays decreased accumulation of Box C/D snoRNAs; overexpression results in a decreased growth rate
DESCRIPTION: Essential protein required for the accumulation of box C/D snoRNA

PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; reduction of function mutant has a competitive fitness defect in minimal medium; repressible mutant displays a reduced accumulation of the large ribosomal subunit (60S) and a defect in the export of the 60S subunit; conditional mutant displays a defect in the nuclear export of Mss4p; heterozygous diploid null mutant has decreased resistance to oxidative stress; overexpression results in a growth defect
DESCRIPTION: Essential protein involved in nuclear export of Mss4p; Mss4p is a lipid kinase that generates phosphatidylinositol 4,5-biphosphate and plays a role in actin cytoskeleton organization and vesicular transport

NAME: ubiquinol-cytochrome c reductase (bc1) Synthesis
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null and point mutants fail to respire and exhibit mitochondrial genome instability and decreased chronological lifespan; in large-scale studies, the null mutant shows reduced competitive fitness, sensitivity to desiccation, heat, and oxidative stress, and sensitivity to various chemicals
DESCRIPTION: Protein translocase and chaperone required for Complex III assembly; member of the AAA ATPase family; forms a homo-oligomeric complex in the mitochondrial inner membrane that translocates the C-terminal domain of Rip1p from the matrix across the inner membrane and delivers it to an assembly intermediate of respiratory Complex III; also required for assembly of the Qcr10p subunit; mutation is functionally complemented by human homolog BCS1L, linked to neonatal diseases

NAME: B Double Prime
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; conditional alleles confer sensitivity to heat and cold; heterozygous diploid null is haploinsufficient and has decreased ethanol tolerance
DESCRIPTION: Essential subunit of RNA polymerase III transcription factor (TFIIIB); TFIIIB is involved in transcription of genes encoding tRNAs, 5S rRNA, U6 snRNA, and other small RNAs

NAME: Blocked Early in Transport
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; overexpression causes abnormalities in cell cycle progression and cell morphology; repression leads to increased chromosome loss and rearrangements
DESCRIPTION: Type II membrane protein required for vesicular transport; required for vesicular transport between the endoplasmic reticulum and Golgi complex; v-SNARE with similarity to synaptobrevins

NAME: Blocked Early in Transport
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; conditional mutants are impaired in protein transport; reduced function mutants show decreased competitive fitness, are sensitive to DNA-damaging agent hydroxyurea (HU); heterozygous diploid nulls are haploinsufficient
DESCRIPTION: Beta subunit of Type II geranylgeranyltransferase; required for vesicular transport between the endoplasmic reticulum and the Golgi; provides a membrane attachment moiety to Rab-like proteins Ypt1p and Sec4p; human homolog RABGGTB can complement yeast BET2 mutant

NAME: Blocked Early in Transport
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutations lead to defects in protein transport and abnormalities in morphology of ER membranes and secretory vesicles
DESCRIPTION: Core component of transport protein particle (TRAPP) complexes I-III; TRAPP complexes are related multimeric guanine nucleotide-exchange factors for the GTPase Ypt1, regulating ER-Golgi traffic (TRAPPI), intra-Golgi traffic (TRAPPII), endosome-Golgi traffic (TRAPPII and III) and autophagy (TRAPPIII); hydrophilic homodimeric protein that acts in conjunction with SNARE proteins in targeting and fusion of ER to Golgi transport vesicles

NAME: Blocked Early in Transport
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; overexpression causes abnormalities in cell cycle progression and cell morphology; conditional (ts) mutants show increased chromosome instability
DESCRIPTION: Alpha subunit of Type II geranylgeranyltransferase; required for vesicular transport between the endoplasmic reticulum and the Golgi; provides a membrane attachment moiety to Rab-like proteins Ypt1p and Sec4p

NAME: Blocked Early in Transport
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; conditional mutants are subject to chromosome instability, have dilated ER, accumulate vesicles, and are impaired in protein transport and secretion at elevated temperatures; heterozygous diploid nulls are haploinsufficient, sensitive to starvation, and to the dopaminergic antagonist chlorpromazine
DESCRIPTION: Core component of transport protein particle (TRAPP) complexes I-III; TRAPP complexes are related multimeric guanine nucleotide-exchange factors for the GTPase Ypt1p, regulating ER-Golgi traffic (TRAPPI), intra-Golgi traffic (TRAPPII), endosome-Golgi traffic (TRAPPII and III) and autophagy (TRAPPIII); human homology TRAPPC1 complements yeast null mutant

NAME: BreFeldin A Resistance
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; repression causes defects in biogenesis of small ribosomal subunits, decreased nuclear export of 40S ribosomal subunits, increased accumulation of 35S pre-rRNA, and decreased levels of 18S and 20S rRNA species
DESCRIPTION: Component of the SSU and 90S preribosomes; involved in pre-18S rRNA processing; binds to U3 snoRNA and Mpp10p; multicopy suppressor of sensitivity to Brefeldin A; expression is induced during lag phase and also by cold shock

NAME: Bad In Glucose
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutation slows down vegetative growth; null mutant cells are very large, often unbudded and multinucleate; repression causes cell cycle delay or arrest in G2 phase
DESCRIPTION: Integral membrane protein of the endoplasmic reticulum; required for normal content of cell wall beta-1,6-glucan

NAME: BMh Sensitive
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; repressible mutant undergoes growth arrest; overexpression in a homozygous diploid background results in enhanced invasive growth
DESCRIPTION: GTPase required for ribosomal subunit synthesis and rRNA processing; required for synthesis of 40S ribosomal subunits and for processing the 35S pre-rRNA at sites A0, A1, and A2; interacts with Rcl1p, which stimulates its GTPase and U3 snoRNA binding activities; has similarity to Tsr1p

NAME: Bet One Suppressor
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; repressible mutant accumulates 40-60 nm secretory vesicles, and an extensive network of endoplasmic reticulum; repressible mutant accumulates a precursor form of carboxypeptidase Y and pro-alpha factor, indicative of a failure in transport of proteins to the Golgi apparatus; reduction of function mutant has decreased competitive fitness in minimal medium and displays increased sensitivity to MMS and hydroxyurea; heterozygous null mutant is haploproficient; overexpression results in a decreased growth rate
DESCRIPTION: v-SNARE (vesicle specific SNAP receptor); localized to the endoplasmic reticulum membrane and necessary for vesicular transport from the ER to the Golgi; required for efficient nuclear fusion during mating

NAME: Biotin:apoProtein Ligase
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; conditional mutants are sensitive to heat, and are subject to chromosome instability; base-substitution mutants are potentially viable and may be isolated as long-chain-fatty-acid-requiring auxotrophs; overexpression slows growth
DESCRIPTION: Biotin:apoprotein ligase; covalently modifies proteins with the addition of biotin, required for acetyl-CoA carboxylase (Acc1p) holoenzyme formation; comparative analysis suggests that a mitochondrially targeted form may result from translation starting at a non-canonical codon upstream of the annotated start codon; human homolog HLCS can complement yeast BPL1 mutant

NAME: B-Related Factor
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; conditional alleles confer sensitivity to heat and cold; repression slows growth; heterozygous diploid null is haploinsufficient; overexpression slows vegetative growth, enhances pseudohyphal growth
DESCRIPTION: TFIIIB B-related factor; one of three subunits of RNA polymerase III transcription initiation factor TFIIIB, binds TFIIIC and TBP and recruits RNA pol III to promoters, amino-terminal half is homologous to TFIIB; mutations in human homolog are associated with autosomal recessive cerebellar-facial-dental syndrome

NAME: BRr6 Like protein
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; conditional mutant is heat and cold sensitive, and slow growing at permissive temperature; repressible mutant has a G1 delay; conditional mutant is sensitive to sterol biosynthesis inhibitors and membrane fluidizing agents, accumulating ergosterol, sterol precursors and monounsaturated fatty acids at permissive temperatures; conditional mutant is defective in the nuclear export of poly(A)+ mRNA, and mislocalizes nuclear pore complex (NPC) cytoplasmic filament proteins; conditional mutant has a nuclear morphology defect with abnormal nuclear envelope, and an abnormal lipid particle arrangement with a circular pattern of droplets surrounding the nucleus; conditional mutant has a strong chromosomal instability phenotype; overexpression results in enhanced pseudohyphal and invasive growth
DESCRIPTION: Essential nuclear envelope/ER integral membrane protein; interacts and functions with Apq12p and Brr6p in lipid homeostasis; mutants are defective in nuclear pore complex biogenesis, mRNA nuclear export and are sensitive to sterol biosynthesis inhibitors and membrane fluidizing agents; identified as a dosage suppressor of a temperature sensitive mutation in the major karyopherin, CRM1; homologous to Brr6p

NAME: homolog of BaRreN
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; conditional mutant undergoes a predominantly heterogenous first cycle arrest with abnormal anaphase spindle morphology, and stretched chromosomes with decreased coordinated movement of pericentromeres; conditional mutant accumulates > 2C DNA content; conditional mutant has chromosome condensation defects, decreased tRNA-mediated silencing and abnormal localization of tRNA to the nuclear periphery rather than the nucleolus; overexpression results in decreased vegetative growth, accumulation of medium to large budded cells with up to 4C DNA content; heterozygous null mutant is haploinsufficient
DESCRIPTION: Subunit of the condensin complex; required for chromosome condensation and for clustering of tRNA genes at the nucleolus; may influence multiple aspects of chromosome transmission

NAME: BCK1-like Resistance to Osmotic shock
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutant has a growth defect, is heat sensitive, and displays decreased competitive fitness on both fermentative and respiratory growth media; null mutant has a decreased ability to use raffinose as carbon source; null mutant has a reduced ability to target Doa4p to the endosome, an inability to sort MVB cargo protein to the vacuole and a strong vacuolar fragmentation defect; null mutant has decreased resistance to ionic stress, cadmium and manganese treatment, oxidative stress, and desiccation; null mutant is defective in regulating intracellular pH and displays decreased resistance to acid pH; null mutant has decreased telomere length, reduced innate thermotolerance, and a decreased ability to form biofilms; null mutant displays increased accumulation of cadmium, calcium and alanine and decreased accumulation of glycogen; homozygous diploid null mutant has a sporulation defect; heterozygous null mutant is haploinsufficient
DESCRIPTION: Cytoplasmic class E vacuolar protein sorting (VPS) factor; coordinates deubiquitination in the multivesicular body (MVB) pathway by recruiting Doa4p to endosomes

NAME: Bad Response to Refrigeration
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; repressible mutant displays decreased accumulation of RPS17A pre-mRNA and loss of spliced mRNA; heterozygous null mutant is haploinsufficient
DESCRIPTION: RNA-dependent ATPase RNA helicase (DEIH box); required for disruption of U4/U6 base-pairing in native snRNPs to activate the spliceosome for catalysis; homologous to human U5-200kD

NAME: Bad Response to Refrigeration
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; conditional mutant is cold sensitive, some alleles are also heat sensitive, and slow growing at permissive temperature; conditional mutant is sensitive to sterol biosynthesis inhibitors and membrane fluidizing agents, accumulating ergosterol, sterol precursors and monounsaturated fatty acids at reduced temperatures; conditional mutant is defective in the export of poly(A)+ mRNA, and mislocalizes nuclear pore complex (NPC) cytoplasmic filament proteins; conditional mutant has a nuclear morphology defect with abnormal nuclear envelope, and an abnormal lipid droplet arrangement with a circular patter of droplets surrounding the nucleus; overexpression results in a decreased growth rate
DESCRIPTION: Essential nuclear envelope integral membrane protein; interacts and functions with Apq12p and Brl1p in lipid homeostasis; mutants are defective in nuclear pore complex biogenesis, nuclear envelope morphology, mRNA nuclear export, and are sensitive to sterol biosynthesis inhibitors and membrane fluidizing agents; exhibits synthetic lethal genetic interactions with genes involved in lipid metabolism; homologous to Brl1p

NAME: Xenopus laevis Brix (Biogenesis of Ribosomes in Xenopus) homolog
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; repressible mutant is defective in the biogenesis of the 60S large ribosomal subunit and has delayed processing of ribosomal rRNA; conditional mutant is heat sensitive, has decreased resistance to killer toxin and increased desiccation resistance; transposon insertion mutant displays a large increase in filamentous growth; heterozygous null mutant is haploinsufficient
DESCRIPTION: Nucleolar protein; constituent of 66S pre-ribosomal particles; depletion leads to defects in rRNA processing and a block in the assembly of large ribosomal subunits; possesses a sigma(70)-like RNA-binding motif

NAME: BUD site selection
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutant has elongated G1 phase and smaller cell size; null mutant shows increased frequency of gross chromosomal rearrangements and accumulates greatly decreased levels of pyridoxal 5'-phosphate; in large-scale studies, null mutant displays random budding pattern, decreased competitive fitness in a variety of media, instability of the mitochondrial genome, and altered resistance to a variety of chemicals
DESCRIPTION: Putative pyridoxal kinase; a key enzyme involved in pyridoxal 5'-phosphate synthesis, the active form of vitamin B6; required for genome integrity; involved in bud-site selection; similarity to yeast BUD17 and human pyridoxal kinase (PDXK)

NAME: Binds Ubiquitin Ligase
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to elevated growth temperatures and resistant to multiple chemicals, including phytosphingosine, rapamycin; in systematic studies null mutants show increased sensitivity to cell wall-affecting drugd caffeine and Congo Red, but increased resistance to several drugs, such as camptothecin, cisplatin, fenpropimorph
DESCRIPTION: Ubiquitin-binding component of the Rsp5p E3-ubiquitin ligase complex; disruption causes temperature-sensitive growth, overexpression causes missorting of amino acid permeases; BUL1 has a paralog, BUL2, that arose from the whole genome duplication

NAME: Bypass UAS Requirement
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; viable but slow-growing under anaerobic conditions; conditional alleles confer sensitivity to cold; reduced function increases competitive fitness
DESCRIPTION: Subunit of a heterodimeric NC2 transcription regulator complex; complex binds to TBP and can repress transcription by preventing preinitiation complex assembly or stimulate activated transcription; homologous to human NC2alpha; complex also includes Ncb2p; bur6 ncb2 double mutation is functionally complemented by coexpression of human DRAP1 and DR1, although the single bur6 mutation is not complemented by its ortholog DRAP1

NAME: Coenzyme A Biosynthesis
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; conditional mutant is heat sensitive; heterozygous diploid null mutant is haploproficient, has a decreased cell size, and decreased resistance to compounds that inhibit fatty acid and sphingolipid biosynthesis; hypomorphic DAmP allele displays decreased competitive fitness on minimal medium
DESCRIPTION: Pantothenate kinase, ATP:D-pantothenate 4'-phosphotransferase; catalyzes the first committed step in the universal biosynthetic pathway for synthesis of coenzyme A (CoA); transcriptionally regulated by Upc2p via a sterol response element

NAME: Coenzyme A Biosynthesis
PHENOTYPE: Null mutants are inviable under standard aerobic conditions, viable under anaerobic conditions, sensitive to zinc deficiency; reduced function mutants show increased competitive fitness; conditional mutants are sensitive to heat
DESCRIPTION: Phosphopantothenoylcysteine synthetase (PPCS); catalyzes the second step of coenzyme A biosynthesis from pantothenate; subunit of the CoA-Synthesizing Protein Complex (CoA-SPC) that contains: Cab2p, Cab3p, Cab4p, Cab5p, Sis2p and Vhs3p subunits; null mutant lethality is complemented by human homolog PPCS and by E. coli coaBC, a bifunctional enzyme with PPCS activity

NAME: Coenzyme A Biosynthesis
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; conditional mutant has increased resistance to killer toxin at elevated temperature; conditional mutant displays a reduction in DNA-damaging agent induced up-regulation of Rnr3p; overexpression results in decrease resistance to ionic stress in lithium chloride treated cells
DESCRIPTION: Subunit of PPCDC and CoA-SPC complexes involved in CoA biosynthesis; subunits of the phosphopantothenoylcysteine decarboxylase (PPCDC) complex are: Cab3p, Sis2p, Vhs3p, while the subunits of the CoA-synthesizing protein complex (CoA-SPC) are: Cab2p, Cab3p, Cab4p, and Cab5p as well as Sis2p and Vhs3p; null mutant lethality is complemented by E. coli coaBC

NAME: Coenzyme A Biosynthesis
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; conditional mutant is heat sensitive
DESCRIPTION: Subunit of the CoA-Synthesizing Protein Complex (CoA-SPC); subunits of this complex are: Cab2p, Cab3p, Cab4p, Cab5p, Sis2p and Vhs3p; probable pantetheine-phosphate adenylyltransferase (PPAT); PPAT catalyzes the fourth step in the biosynthesis of coenzyme A from pantothenate; null mutant lethality is complemented by E. coli coaD (encoding PPAT) and by human COASY

PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; conditional mutants accumulate decreased amounts of 18S rRNA at elevated temperatures; reduced function mutants show increased competitive fitness; repression causes sensitivity to the TDP-43 human RNA-binding protein that forms inclusions and aggregates in ALS disease models; overexpression slows growth, induces chromosome instability; heterozygous diploid nulls are haploinsufficient
DESCRIPTION: Subunit of the CoA-Synthesizing Protein Complex (CoA-SPC); subunits of this complex are: Cab2p, Cab3p, Cab4p, Cab5p, Sis2p and Vhs3p; probable dephospho-CoA kinase (DPCK) that catalyzes the last step in coenzyme A biosynthesis; null mutant lethality is complemented by human homolog DCAKD and by E. coli coaE (encoding DPCK); detected in purified mitochondria in high-throughput studies; also localized to lipid droplets

NAME: Cdk-Activating Kinase
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; heterozygous diploid null mutant displays chromosomal instability, decreased starvation resistance and decreased resistance to the antibiotic sulfanilamide
DESCRIPTION: Cyclin-dependent kinase-activating kinase; required for passage through the cell cycle; phosphorylates and activates Cdc28p; nucleotide-binding pocket differs significantly from those of most other protein kinases

NAME: CATabolite repression
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutant is incapable of respiratory growth on non-fermentable carbon sources; null mutant is also sensitive to oxidative stress and linoleic acid; in systematic studies null mutation results in reduced competitive fitness
DESCRIPTION: Protein required for ubiquinone (Coenzyme Q) biosynthesis; localizes to the matrix face of the mitochondrial inner membrane in a large complex with ubiquinone biosynthetic enzymes; required for gluconeogenic gene activation

NAME: CATabolite repression
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows abnormal vacuolar morphology, respiration defects, decreased lifespan and competitive fitness, and is sensitive to dessication; homozygous diploid null is impaired in sporulation; overexpression slows growth
DESCRIPTION: Zinc cluster transcriptional activator; necessary for derepression of a variety of genes under non-fermentative growth conditions, active after diauxic shift, binds carbon source responsive elements; relative distribution to the nucleus increases upon DNA replication stress

NAME: Centromere-Binding Factor
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutants show abnormal spindle morphology and elevated chromosome instability; overexpression causes slow growth and increased chromosome loss and rearrangements
DESCRIPTION: Essential kinetochore protein; component of the CBF3 multisubunit complex that binds to the CDEIII region of the centromere; Cbf2p also binds to the CDEII region possibly forming a different multimeric complex, ubiquitinated in vivo; sumoylated in an Mms21p-dependent manner; relative distribution to the spindle pole body decreases upon DNA replication stress

NAME: Centromere Binding Factor
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; reduction of function leads to lack of pseudouridylation of mRNA, decreased competitive fitness, increased telomere length and decreased silencing
DESCRIPTION: Pseudouridine synthase catalytic subunit of box H/ACA snoRNPs; acts on large and small rRNAs, on snRNA U2, and on some mRNAs; mutations in human ortholog dyskerin cause the disorder dyskeratosis congenita; small nucleolar ribonucleoprotein particles are also known as snoRNPs

NAME: Cell wall Biosynthesis Kinase
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutant has defects in actin cytoskeleton and shows abnormal budding pattern, round cell shape, crinkled colony appearance and increased cell aggregation in liquid cultures; null mutant is also defective in mating projection formation; null mutants in Sigma1278b are incapable of invasive growth
DESCRIPTION: Serine/threonine protein kinase of the the RAM signaling network; Ndr/LATS family member; binds regulatory subunit Mob2p; involved in regulation of cellular morphogenesis, polarized growth, and septum destruction; phosphorylation by Cbk1p regulates localization and activity of Ace2p transcription factor and Ssd1p translational repressor; Cbk1p activity is regulated by both phosphorylation and specific localization; relocalizes to cytoplasm upon DNA replication stress

NAME: Cytochrome B mRNA Processing
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; mutants are incapable of respiratory growth on non-fermentable carbon sources; conditional mutant fails to accumulate cytochrome B (COB) mRNA under restrictive conditions; in systematic studies null mutants show decreased chronological lifespan and reduced competitive fitness
DESCRIPTION: Mitochondrial protein, regulator of COB mRNA stability and translation; interacts with the 5'-untranslated region of the COB mRNA; found in a complex at the inner membrane along with Pet309p; localizes to mitochondrial foci upon DNA replication stress

NAME: Cytochrome B mRNA Processing
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutant diploid shows reduced rate of respiratory growth on non-fermentable carbon sources; in systematic studies null mutants show decreased chronological lifespan and competitive fitness
DESCRIPTION: Required for splicing of the group I intron bI5 of the COB pre-mRNA; nuclear-encoded mitochondrial protein that binds to the RNA to promote splicing; also involved in but not essential for splicing of the COB bI2 intron and the intron in the 21S rRNA gene

NAME: Cytochrome B mRNA Processing
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; in systematic studies, null mutants are incapable of respiratory growth on non-fermentable carbon sources, grow slowly on fermentable carbon sources and show reduced competitive fitness
DESCRIPTION: Mitochondrial protein required for assembly of cytochrome bc1 complex; forms a complex with Cbp6p that binds to mt ribosomes near the polypeptide tunnel exit and promotes efficient translation of the COB mRNA; Cbp3p-Cbp6p complex also interacts with newly synthesized cytochrome b (Cobp) and Cbp4p to promote assembly of Cobp into the cytochrome bc1 complex; Cbp3p-Cbp6p complex is sequestered if assembly of Complex III is blocked, downregulating COB mRNA translation

NAME: Cytochrome B mRNA Processing
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; in systematic studies, null mutants show reduced rate of respiratory growth on non-fermentable carbon sources, grows slowly on fermentable carbon sources and shows reduced competitive fitness
DESCRIPTION: Mitochondrial protein required for assembly of cytochrome bc1 complex; interacts with the Cbp3p-Cbp6p complex and newly synthesized cytochrome b (Cobp) to promote assembly of Cobp into the cytochrome bc1 complex

NAME: Cytochrome B Synthesis
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutation causes accumulation of unspliced COB and COX1 mRNA precursors; null mutant is unable to grow on non-fermentable carbon sources and shows reduced autophagy
DESCRIPTION: Mitochondrial translational activator of the COB mRNA; membrane protein that interacts with translating ribosomes, acts on the COB mRNA 5'-untranslated leader

NAME: Cytochrome B Synthesis
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutation causes accumulation of unspliced COB and COX1 mRNA precursors and inability to grow on non-fermentable carbon sources; in systematic studies null mutants show slow growth rate, increased resistance to azoles and reduced competitive fitness
DESCRIPTION: Mitochondrial translational activator of the COB mRNA; interacts with translating ribosomes, acts on the COB mRNA 5'-untranslated leader

NAME: Cytochrome B Termination
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows 'petite' phenotype (formation of small colonies on fermentable carbon sources due to respiratory defect); in systematic studies mutants show reduced competitive fitness and increased resistance to bleomycin, camptothecin, fenpropimorph, tunicamycin
DESCRIPTION: Protein involved in 5' RNA end processing; substrates include mitochondrial COB, 15S_rRNA, and RPM1 transcripts; may also have a role in 3' end processing of the COB pre-mRNA; displays genetic interaction with cell cycle-regulated kinase Dbf2p

NAME: tRNA CCA-pyrophosphorylase
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; base-substitution mutants grow slowly and are sensitive to heat
DESCRIPTION: ATP (CTP):tRNA-specific tRNA nucleotidyltransferase; different forms targeted to the nucleus, cytosol, and mitochondrion are generated via the use of multiple transcriptional and translational start sites; human homolog TRNT1 complements yeast null mutant

NAME: Cross-Complements Ca(2+) phenotype of csg1
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows sensitivity to alkaline pH that can be rescued by iron supplementation; null mutant grows slowly in iron or copper-limited medium; in large-scale studies, null mutant exhibits decreased competitive fitness, sensitivity to metal ions, decreased or absent respiratory growth, and sensitivity to various chemicals
DESCRIPTION: Cu(+2)-transporting P-type ATPase; required for export of copper from the cytosol into an extracytosolic compartment; similar to human proteins involved in Menkes and Wilsons diseases; protein abundance increases in response to DNA replication stress; affects TBSV model (+)RNA virus replication by regulating copper metabolism; human homologs ATP7A and ATP7B both complement yeast null mutant

PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; base-substitution mutants are resistant to cycloheximide; reduced function mutants show increased competitive fitness; heterozygous diploid nulls are haploinsufficient and sensitive to lactoferricin, which is an amphipathic, cationic peptide with antimicrobial and anticancer properties
DESCRIPTION: Cyclin associated with protein kinase Kin28p; Kin28p is the TFIIH-associated carboxy-terminal domain (CTD) kinase involved in transcription initiation at RNA polymerase II promoters; human homolog CCNH allows growth of yeast ccl1 temperature-sensitive mutant at restrictive temperature

NAME: COB and COX1 mRNA maturation
PHENOTYPE: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows 'petite' phenotype (formation of small colonies on fermentable carbon sources due to respiratory defect); null mutation leads to abnormalities in mitochondrial splicing and genome maintenance
DESCRIPTION: Mitochondrial 15S rRNA-binding protein; required for intron removal of COB and COX1 pre-mRNAs; has separable roles in stabilizing mitochondrial 15S rRNA and in maturation of the COB and COX1 mRNAs; contains pentatricopeptide repeat (PPR) motifs; mutant is respiratory deficient and has defective plasma membrane electron transport

NAME: Chaperonin Containing TCP-1
PHENOTYPE: Essential gene; reduction of function leads to sensitivity to translation-interfering drugs, such as azetidine-2-carboxylic acid, cycloheximide, hygromycin
